questions.text: All are components of Basic Life Support (BLS), except:
questions.solution:
Needle cricothyrotomy is not a component of BLS. It is a component of Advanced Life Support (ALS).

Components of BLS:

  • Airway - Manual
  • Breathing - Bag and Mask
  • Circulation - Cardiac massage

questions.text: While working out at the gymnasium, you witness a weightlifter collapse. What is the correct sequence to be followed to provide basic life support to this victim?

choices.text: Verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, check for pulse, call the emergency response team, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Verify scene safety, call the emergency response team,  assess responsiveness, check for pulse, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation(CPR)
Verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, check for pulse , commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Verify scene safety, check for pulse,  assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)

questions.solution:
Basic life support should be provided in the following sequence for a witnessed collapse: verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, check for pulse, and then commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

First, assess scene safety to ensure the environment is safe for the rescuers and the victim.

The next step is to check for responsiveness. If unresponsive, activate the emergency response system and get the automated external defibrillator (AED) before starting CPR if you are alone. Otherwise, send someone to activate the response system and get the automated external defibrillator (AED).

Check the patient for a carotid pulse for 5-10 seconds. If the patient has a pulse but no normal breathing or only gasping, provide 1 breath every 6 seconds or 10-12 rescue breaths /minute and recheck pulse every 2 minutes.

If the patient does not have a pulse and is not breathing, proceed to provide high-quality CPR.

Continuous chest compressions should be given on the lower 1/3rd of the patient's sternum by pushing hard and fast at the rate of 100-120/minute, at a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5-6 cm) allowing complete chest recoil after every compression. Rescue breaths are given every 6 seconds or 10-12 breaths/minute.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty should be at the compression rate is 100 - 120/min  (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec), depth of 2 inches by pressing hard and fast. Allow for full chest recoil after every compression. Minimize interruptions in chest compression to less than 10 seconds.

Analyze if it is a shockable rhythm when the AED arrives. If it is shockable, then give one shock and proceed with CPR. If it is a non-shockable rhythm then continue CPR immediately.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: You are posted as a junior resident in the Emergency Medicine department, where you have to resuscitate an 11-month-old infant who is not breathing and you cannot get the pulse. According to the AHA 2020 guidelines for the pediatric basic and advanced life support, you would be correct to perform all of the following steps except:

choices.text: Use a cuffed endotracheal tube for intubating this child
Apply cricoid pressure  during endotracheal intubation
Administer the initial dose of epinephrine within 5 minutes from the start of chest compressions

questions.solution:
According to the AHA 2020 guidelines, routine use of cricoid pressure is not recommended during the endotracheal intubation of pediatric patients.

It is reasonable to choose cuffed ETTs over uncuffed ETTs for intubating infants and children. When a cuffed ETT is used, attention should be paid to tube size, position, and cuff inflation pressure (usually <20-25 cm H2O).

For infants and children with a pulse but an absent or inadequate respiratory effort, it is reasonable to give 1 breath every 2 to 3 seconds (20-30 breaths/min). For pediatric patients in any setting, it is reasonable to administer the initial dose of epinephrine within 5 minutes from the start of chest compressions.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect about the appropriate use of an automated external defibrillator (AED) during resuscitation?

CPR: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation

choices.text: Does not deliver shock if asystole is detected
CPR is continued during rhythm analysis
Pads are placed in anterior-lateral or anterior-posterior positions

questions.solution:
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) should be paused during rhythm analysis as AEDs cannot recognize the shockable rhythms accurately if CPR is continued. 

AED is a special medical device that is commonly used for recognizing the absence/presence of rapid ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, hence identifying a shockable rhythm autonomously if present. Below is an image of an AED.

As a rule, AED is used together with CPR in cases of sudden cardiac arrest. The machine guides the user to place two electrode pads on the patient's exposed chest: in the anterior-lateral or anterior-posterior positions (Option D). Wet skin can interfere with shock delivery. Therefore, skin is dried at the site of pad placement as required before shock delivery. Anterior-lateral placement is used for adults in which one pad is placed above the nipple on the right side of the chest, and one pad is placed below the nipple on the left side of the chest. In anterior-posterior placement, one pad is placed anteriorly on the chest and the other on the back. Given below is a diagram demonstrating the placement of these pads in both the anterior-lateral and anterior-posterior positions.

AED can determine whether an electric shock is needed by analyzing the rhythm.  CPR should be stopped while the machine is analyzing the rhythm. If the rhythm is not shockable, CPR is immediately resumed. If there is a shockable rhythm, a shock will be delivered and CPR is resumed for 2 minutes before analyzing the rhythm again.  

The shock energy for defibrillation is as follows: 

  • Biphasic: Initial dose of 120-200J (according to manufacturer recommendations). Second and subsequent doses should be equivalent (higher doses can be considered).
  • Monophasic: 360J
  • Pediatric: First shock 2J/Kg, second shock 4J/Kg, subsequent shocks ≥ 4J/Kg, maximum 10J/Kg or adult dose.

Other options:

Option A: Included among non-shockable rhythms are pulseless electrical activity (PEA) and asystole. Hence, AEDs do not deliver a shock if these two rhythms are detected during resuscitation.

Option B: In the presence of shockable rhythyms such as rapid ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation a 200J biphasic waveform is delivered.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child, weighing 20 kg presents to the emergency room with partial to full-thickness burns covering 20% of his total body surface area. As per the ATLS guidelines, the volume of fluids that need to be administered over 24 hours in this patient is?
questions.solution:
The child needs fluid resuscitation with 1.2 L of ringer lactate in 24 hours. 

According to the 10th Edition of ATLS (2018), fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient < 14 years should begin at 3 ml of lactated Ringer’s x % TBSA x patient’s body weight in kg for second and third-degree burns. 

In this case, 20 (% TBSA) x 20 (body weight in kg) x 3 = 1200ml

Therefore, the total volume of RL to be given is 1.2 litres.

Note:

The superficial/1st-degree burns are not considered for the formula. Only the % TBSA of 2nd and 3rd-degree burns is calculated for the formula.

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain a fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A victim of a road traffic accident is brought to the casualty department. Which of the following is a part of step 'D' under A-B-C-D-E of trauma care?

choices.text: GCS scoring for basic neurologic evaluation

questions.solution:
GCS scoring for basic neurologic evaluation is a part of step D-Disability assessment of trauma care.

Steps in the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS):

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood - FBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done in pregnant women.

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text:
Arrange the following patients in descending order of treatment priority as per the triage system.
  1. A young man with tension pneumothorax
  2. A middle-aged man with a simple fracture of the ulna
  3. A middle-aged woman with a degloving injury of the left leg
  4. A teenage girl with severe brain injury and major chest wall and abdominal injuries
questions.solution:
Option C is the correct sequence of triage colour coding.

  • A young man with tension pneumothorax - Red - Highest priority
  • A middle-aged woman with a degloving injury of the left leg - Yellow - Medium priority
  • A middle-aged man with a simple fracture of the ulna - Green - Low priority
  • A teenage girl with severe brain injury and major chest wall and abdominal injuries - Black - Least priority

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment. It is carried out at the disaster site to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. It provides maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a disaster situation. Higher priority is given to victims whose prognosis would be good with simple medical care. Lower priority is given to moribund patients who would have questionable benefits even with medical attention.

Priority Color Medical need Clinical status
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if the treatment is given early
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive if the treatment is given within hours
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Note:

In the event of a disaster, mass casualty or epidemic, hospitals face a significant demand or a surge for healthcare services that often outpaces the supply of available resources. Reverse triage is implemented during these surge periods.

By identifying and discharging low-risk patients, reverse triage allows faster and more efficient treatment of critically ill patients. It also helps minimize mortality and morbidity for the greatest number of patients while treating the largest number of patients in the shortest period of time.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A 10-month-old child who was unresponsive and cyanotic was brought to the emergency. Which of the following is the recommended site to check for pulselessness before initiating CPR?
questions.solution:
The brachial artery is palpated in infants to check for pulselessness before initiating CPR.

The pulse should be checked at the carotid artery for children aged one and above. 

The short neck of children <1 year of age makes the rapid location of the carotid artery difficult. There is a risk of compressing the airway while attempting to palpate a carotid pulse in the infant’s neck. Therefore, it is recommended to palpate the brachial pulse before initiating CPR in infants. The brachial pulse is palpated on the inside of the upper arm, between the infant’s elbow and shoulder. The inside of the upper arm is pressed with the index and middle fingers gently for no more than 10 seconds. 

Chest compressions in infants are given by placing two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below it if only one provider is available. The torso is encircled by the palms of both hands with the thumbs pointing cephalad and positioned 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum.

The depth of compressions in infants should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below the first finger
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands, thumbs pointing cephalad and positioned 1cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth in infants (<1 year). 
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The heel of the palm on the lower 1/3rd of the sternum is applied during chest compression
  • The depth of compression is 2 inches or 1/3 the depth of the patient's chest.

Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths i.e. 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if the second rescuer arrives).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man was brought to the casualty unconscious and pale, with agonal respirations and without a pulse. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidaemia, 40 pack-years of cigarette smoking and was witnessed falling to the ground suddenly at home. He had not complained of any preceding symptoms. A cardiac monitor was connected and the following tracing was obtained. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient is in cardiac arrest and the rhythm shown is ventricular fibrillation. The next step in management is immediate defibrillation.

It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate at the earliest because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm. The energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator: 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator: 120-200 J

Note - The management of ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia is the same. Chest compressions are to be started following defibrillation.

Other options

Option B - Synchronized cardioversion is used in unstable tachyarrhythmias. It is not used in cardiac arrests.

Option C - Adenosine is used in regular narrow complex tachycardia and in stable wide complex tachycardia with monomorphic QRS complexes. It is not used in cardiac arrests.

Option D - Epinephrine is used after administering defibrillation and also in non-shockable rhythms (asystole and pulseless electrical activity).

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: An obese patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident.  He was diagnosed with tension pneumothorax. An immediate needle thoracotomy was performed in spite of which the vitals did not improve. What will be your next best step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Refer the patient immediately to tertiary care centre
Perform an eFAST to confirm the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The next best step for this patient would be to perform a finger thoracostomy.

According to ATLS, due to the variable thickness of the chest wall (here the patient is obese), kinking of the catheter, and other technical or anatomic complications, needle decompression may not be successful always. In this case, finger thoracostomy is an alternative approach and is recommended as the next best step.

Advantages of finger thoracostomy over needle thoracostomy:

  • Not limited by needle length
  • Observable signs confirming pleural access
    • Puncture sensation of parietal pleura with Kelly/finger
    • Palpation of parietal pleura with finger
    • Palpation of lung parenchyma with finger
  • If there is no pneumothorax, this will not puncture lung parenchyma and create a new pneumothorax
  • No risk of catheter "kinking"

Advantages of finger thoracostomy over tube thoracostomy:

  • Simpler, quicker, easier, and requires less equipment
  • No foreign body hence decreased risk of infection

However, it is mandatory to perform a Tube thoracostomy after a successful needle or finger decompression of the chest.

The RECENT UPDATE (Acc. to ATLS 10th edition):

  • In adults, the needle thoracotomy location changed to the 5th ICS mid-axillary line from the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, the thoracotomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He is found to be in hemorrhagic shock. As a part of the ATLS protocol, which of the following cannula should be preferred for fluid resuscitation in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to ATLS guidelines, a minimum of 2 large bore IV lines preferably of 18 gauge (green) marked as "1" should be used for fluid resuscitation of trauma patients with large volume loss.

For trauma patients who necessitate a high volume of fluid replacement and multiple blood transfers large-sized, wide-bored cannulas are preferred.

The rate of flow is proportional to the fourth power of the radius of the cannula and inversely related to its length, as described in Poiseuille’s law. Hence, short, large-caliber peripheral intravenous lines are preferred for the rapid infusion of fluid, rather than longer, thinner catheters. Higher the gauge of the cannula, lower the caliber of the cannula.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

Size Color Coding Flow Rate Uses
14G Orange 270ml/min Trauma Patients, Rapid, Large Volume replacement
16G Grey 236ml/min Trauma Patients, Major Surgery, Intra Partum/Post Partum, GI bleeds, Multiple blood transfers, High volume of Fluids
17G White 125ml/min Newly added
18G Green 103 ml/min Blood products, delivery of irritant medications, major surgery, contrast study
20G Pink 67ml/min General use IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, IV analgesics

questions.text:
In which of the following cases of cardiac arrest the use of defibrillators is not recommended?
  1. Asystole
  2. Ventricular fibrillation
  3. Pulseless ventricular tachycardia
  4. Pulseless electrical activity
questions.solution:
In cases of asystole and pulseless electrical activity the use of a defibrillator, during resuscitation for cardiac arrest, is not recommended.

Defibrillation involves the depolarization of the entire myocardium by the therapeutic use of electric current to eliminate cardiac rhythms associated with cardiac arrest. This resets the myocardium and normal sinus rhythm is restored.

Shockable rhythms of cardiac arrest include ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia. Non-shockable rhythms of cardiac arrest include asystole and pulseless electrical activity.

Asystole is the complete and sustained absence of electrical activity. It is usually seen as a terminal rhythm in a resuscitation attempt that started with another rhythm, or in a patient with unwitnessed or prolonged cardiac arrest. The prognosis for persistent asystole is poor. A pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

questions.text: A man presents to the ER with a gunshot wound to the abdomen as shown below. On examination, the peritoneum is breached. BP is 114/78 mmHg and HR is 80 bpm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for a patient with a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a breach of the peritoneum is laparotomy.

The incidence of significant injury to the intraperitoneal organs increases manifold when there is a breach of the peritoneum due to any penetrating trauma injury. The indications for doing laparotomy in patients with penetrating abdominal wounds include:

  • Hemodynamic instability
  • Gunshot wound which breaches the peritoneum
  • Evisceration
  • Bleeding from the stomach, rectum, or genitourinary tract following penetrating trauma
  • Peritonitis
  • Free air in the peritoneal cavity
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage has bile, gastrointestinal contents or ≥10 cc of blood

CT scan of the abdomen (option B) should be performed in patients with blunt or penetrating abdominal trauma, provided they are hemodynamically stable and have no indication for immediate laparotomy. The patient in question has a gunshot wound to the anterior abdominal wall with a peritoneal breach, which is an indication for exploratory laparotomy as it carries a high risk of organ injury. FAST (option C) is primarily indicated in patients with blunt abdominal trauma with or without hemodynamic instability. It is not a sensitive investigation to detect hollow visceral injury in patients with penetrating abdominal trauma. There is no role for observation (option D) in this patient.

questions.text: A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs will not be used in his management?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation followed by CPR and amiodarone, adrenaline, and lidocaine given alternatively as per the ACLS guidelines. Verapamil is not a part of the ACLS algorithm for the management of VF. (Option A)

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

Along with defibrillation, CPR should be given for 2 minutes and alternated with Epinephrine 1mg or Lidocaine/Amiodarone. At the same time, any reversible causes of Vfib should be treated.

questions.text: According to CRASH-2 trials, tranexamic acid has a role in the reduction of mortality in patients with trauma. Within how many hours of injury should it be administered to a patient with a history of trauma?
questions.solution:
Tranexamic acid needs to be administered within 3 hours of injury. It is an antifibrinolytic drug that reduces the risk of mortality from bleeding in both blunt and penetrating trauma.

1g is given intravenously over 10 minutes, followed by a further 1 g dose over 8 hours. Tranexamic acid should be given to all trauma patients suspected to have a significant haemorrhage, including those with a systolic blood pressure of <110 mmHg or a pulse of over 110 per minute.

It is imperative to administer the treatment as early as possible, ideally within the initial hour following the injury. The initial dose should not be administered more than 3 hours after the injury occurred.

The CRASH-2 trial has shown mortality reduction in bleeding trauma patients by early usage of tranexamic acid.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident and eFAST was performed on him. Which among the following statements is true regarding eFAST?

choices.text: It detects free fluid in the abdomen or pericardium
It helps in assessment of retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
eFAST/extended FAST helps in detecting free fluid in the abdomen and pericardium. 

Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) aims to identify intra-abdominal free fluid (assumed to be hemoperitoneum in the context of trauma) allowing for an immediate transfer for surgery or for CT imaging and further workup.

The standard order of evaluation is:

  • Pericardial (subxiphoid)
  • Right flank (perihepatic view or Morison's pouch)
  • Left flank (perisplenic view)
  • Pelvic (retrovesical views)

eFAST (Extended FAST) is used to assess pleural (pneumothorax and hemothorax evaluation), pericardial region, right flank, left flank, and pelvic region. It is accurate in detecting >100 ml of free blood. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose. It is also unreliable in excluding injury in penetrating trauma. It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

questions.text: How many healthcare providers are required to safely remove a helmet as per the ATLS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Removing a helmet properly is a procedure that requires two individuals as per ATLS 10th edition.

First-person restricts the cervical spine motion while the second person tries to expand the helmet laterally. Then, the second person gently removes the helmet, ensuring that the nose and occiput are cleared with ease. After the helmet is removed, the first person supports the weight of the patient’s head and the second person takes over cervical spine motion restriction.

questions.text: National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study (NEXUS) criteria in a trauma patient are related to the ______ spine.
questions.solution:
NEXUS criteria are related to the cervical spine injury.

In trauma patients, without the need for radiologic imaging, the decision to discontinue the cervical c-spine collar can be made using the clinical tools namely:

  • National Emergency X-Radiography Utilization Study (NEXUS)
  • Canadian C-spine rule (CCR)

NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is met then radiography is done to evaluate further.

The NEXUS criteria include:

  1. No posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness
  2. No evidence of intoxication
  3. A normal level of alertness
  4. No focal neurologic deficit
  5. No painful distracting injuries

Canadian C-spine rule: The rule is applicable to patients who are in an alert (Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15) and stable condition following trauma.

questions.text: You are providing cardiopulmonary resuscitation to an unconscious adult patient. Which of the following statements correctly describes effective chest compressions?

choices.text: Full chest recoil is avoided between 2 compressions
The chest is pressed to a depth of 4 inches
Given at lower half of the sternum

questions.solution:
Effective chest compressions in BLS are given on the lower half of the patient's sternum at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).

Adequate chest compressions create blood flow by increasing the intrathoracic pressure and directly compressing the heart.

2015 AHA guidelines for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) recommend a chest compression of 100-120/min, a depth for adults of at least 2 inches. 

Components of high-quality CPR include compressing the chest at an adequate rate and depth. Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression. Minimizing interruptions in compressions and should avoid excessive ventilation.

Effective chest compression in adults:

  • Provide 15 chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute.
  • Place your arms, one over the other in the midline, on the lower half of the patient's sternum, and lock your arms.
  • Use both arms to press the chest to a depth of 5- 6cm
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: As per ACLS, CPR can be considered to be of high quality when ETCO2 is _____.
questions.solution:
As per ACLS, CPR can be considered to be of high quality when ETCO2 is at least 10-20 mmHg.

Failure to maintain ETCO2 at >10 mm Hg during adult CPR is a reflection of poor cardiac output and it is found to strongly predicts unsuccessful resuscitation.

Monitoring ETCO2 during CPR can be used to assess blood flow in 2 ways:

  • To improve chest compression performance if ETCO2 is <10 mm Hg during CPR
  • To consider an abrupt sustained increase to a normal value (35 to 40 mm Hg) as an indicator of ROSC

High-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR):

  • Push hard (at least 5 cm) and fast (100–120/min) and allow complete chest recoil.
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions (10 seconds or less).
  • Avoid excessive ventilation.
  • Rotate the compressor every 2 minutes or earlier if fatigued.
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression- ventilation ratio.
  • Quantitative waveform capnography– If PetCO2 <10 mm Hg, attempt to improve CPR quality.
  • Intra-arterial pressure: If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20 mm Hg, attempt to improve CPR quality.

Effective chest compression in adults:

  • Provide 100–120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).
  • Place your arms, one over the other in the midline, on the lower 1/3rd of the patient's sternum, and lock your arms.
  • Use both arms to press the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm (2–2.4 inches)or more.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty:

  • The compression rate is 100–120/min  (30 compressions for every 15–18 sec).
  • One or both palms are placed in the midline.
  • Depth of compression is 2 inches.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Effective chest compressions in infants (<1 year):

  • 100 to 120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15–18 sec).
  • One provider: Place two fingers, one between the nipple line and the other 1 cm below.
  • Two providers: Encircle the infant's torso with both hands with both thumbs pointing cephalic positioned 1 cm below the nipples over the sternum. 
  • Depth of compressions should be at least 1.5 inches or 1/3 the depth of the infant’s chest.
  • Press hard and fast
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg
